docs.lead_paragraph: FOR three years now, ever since abandoning a full-time job at age 66, I've been keeping track of the responses from friends and acquaintances to the statement, ''I'm retired.'' In general, younger people have congratulated me on my new-found freedom: ''You're a lucky guy!'' The reaction from older people has been more reserved, even concerned: ''What are you going to do with yourself? How will you manage?'' We all think we know what the word retirement means but our definitions vary wildly, and they are mostly wrong. We have been misled by a host of retirement myths. Among them: Retirees happily leave their jobs at age 65 and never work again. They live on their pensions, with a little help from Social Security. They either (1) Spend a few years playing cards until it's time for the nursing home, or (2) Endlessly travel the world while starting new businesses and rediscovering romance.

headline.main: Not an Age, but an Expanding State of Mind

docs.abstract: Article by retiree Robert W Stock holds views of retirement vary widely and are mostly wrong; notes way Americans retire and think about retirement has changed over last few decades, with more change on way; cites abrupt halt in decades-long drop in retirement age and tendency of many retirees to take easier, often part-time jobs; graphs of increasing number of older Americans; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Amy Salvatore looked over her auto insurance bill last month, she figured that she could save about $300 a year by eliminating coverage for theft and collision on her 10-year-old Chevy Astro minivan. With a $500 deductible, she said the extra protection was hardly worth it. She had long ago dropped collision on the 1982 Ford pickup that her husband, Thomas, a carpenter, uses for work.

headline.main: Auto Insurance Crash Course; Getting the Best Premiums Is More Complex Than Ever

docs.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of New Jersey drivers are discovering that, under new auto insurance law, their premiums can actually increase if they drop some coverage; new options and restrictions outlined; table; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THINKING of starting or investing in a business to serve retired people? The monthly luncheon of the Desert Newcomers, a club for retired women who recently moved to Las Vegas, might be a good place to do market research, except for one hitch. The ladies do not like to talk business. Desert Newcomers is strictly a social club. But when Joy Schott, 82, reeled off a laundry list of businesses that could serve retirees better, the other women at her luncheon table nodded in agreement at the needs and desires that someone might make money satisfying:

headline.main: What Does Joy Schott Want? Wall Street Is Listening

docs.lead_paragraph: THE darkest clouds have finally parted over Connecticut's insurance industry. Mergers are smaller; layoffs are a sprinkle of what they were earlier in the 90's, and many companies have begun hiring again. Still, the gloom hasn't completely disappeared, and the industry's future, say economists and analysts, won't ever be as bright as in decades past.
docs.abstract: Article on restructuring of Connecticut's insurance industry, dominated in early 1990's by mergers and layoffs; experts comment on erosion of industry's influence and changes in corporate culture; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HERE is a secret about the perfect retirement plan: It doesn't exist. Here is another secret about all retirement plans: They are educated guesses, because they deal with that most unpredictable of things, the future.

headline.main: Building a Nest Egg: An Exercise in Constant Guesswork

docs.lead_paragraph: Residents of a five-story walk-up on the West Side of Manhattan fled their building yesterday after two passers-by climbed the fire escape, banging on windows to alert them to a fire that had broken out on the top floor. The four-alarm fire gutted the top floor of the building at 45th Street and 10th Avenue, dislodging 16 families and tying up traffic as far south as Canal Street. Twelve people, including eight firefighters, were injured, most of them from smoke inhalation.

headline.main: 2 Passers-By Help Families To Escape Building Fire

docs.lead_paragraph: With Nassau County worrying about growing debt and the owner of the New York Islanders thinking about football, plans for a new Nassau Coliseum for the hockey team are in doubt. The team is up for sale, and county officials, who two months ago were saying that there had been ''tremendous progress'' made on a deal to build the Islanders a new sports complex, now say the negotiations are at a standstill.

headline.main: A New Arena For Islanders Hits a Snag

docs.lead_paragraph: A Senate committee approved legislation tonight to create a wide range of new rights for patients, but Democrats said the protections fell far short of what was needed to help people deal with insurance companies and health maintenance organizations. The question of patients' rights stirs more public interest than many issues before Congress, and today's battle was only the first stage of a conflict likely to continue into next year's elections.

headline.main: A G.O.P. Bill On the Rights Of Patients Advances

docs.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West at 79th Street. Exhibition highlights include the Hall of Biodiversity, which focuses on the variety and interdependence of living things. ''Epidemic! The World of Infectious Disease'' examines how best to control the spread of disease worldwide; through Sept. 6. ''AIDS as Global Pandemic: Building Bridges,'' an all-day conference on the global and local issues affecting patients and those who care for them, tomorrow 10:30 A.M. to 8:30 P.M. in the first floor Kaufmann Theater. Free with museum admission. Tomorrow and Sunday, ''Women of the World: Diverse Perspectives,'' a film, lecture and performance series. ''A Life Without Fear,'' a 1994 video produced by Sakhi, an advocacy organization for survivors of violence in New York, portrays the struggles facing immigrant South Asian woman. A discussion will follow the video, at 1 P.M. A lecture on immigrant women's experiences, including battered women and the community's response, at 2 and 3:30 P.M. A performance by the dancer Swati Bhise, with the singer Savitri Ramanand and the mridangam drummer Murali Balachandran, at 2:30 and 4 P.M. ''Primates: The Jean Baulu Collection of Antique Prints,'' about 50 prints and three books ranging from the 1600's to the present. Closes April 25. Photographs from E. T. Gilliard's 1953-54 expedition to the Middle Sepik River in Papua New Guinea. Closes March 28. The Imax films are ''Africa's Elephant Kingdom'' and ''Amazon.'' Through June. In the Imax Theater on Friday and Saturday nights at 9, ''U2 in 3-D,'' and at 10, ''Pink Floyd's 'Dark Side of the Moon' in 3-D.'' Tickets: $9. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8:45 P.M.; suggested admission: $8; students and the elderly, $6; children 12 and under, $4.50; under 2, free. A combination ticket including museum admission and one film or any special exhibition: $13; students and the elderly, $9; children 12 and under, $7; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100; to buy tickets by phone: (212) 769-5200. AMERICAN NUMISMATIC SOCIETY, Audubon Terrace, Broadway at 155th Street, Washington Heights. The society has the most extensive coin collection in North America; its library is open to the public. On permanent display is ''American Numismatic Design: 1892-1922,'' which includes all coins issued during this period. Also on view is ''The World of Coins,'' a history beginning in 600 B.C. Free. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 4 P.M. Information: (212) 234-3130.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate Budget Committee approved the Republican tax and spending plan today as the Clinton Administration and Congressional Democrats stepped up their attacks on the measure and labeled it irresponsible. The committee sent the fiscal blueprint to the full Senate on a 11-to-9 vote along party lines after three days of debate. Both the House and the Senate will vote on the plan next week, and unlike last year, when the Republican Party was split over how hard to push for tax cuts, Republicans appear united and all but certain to adopt the bill.

headline.main: Senate Committee Passes G.O.P. Budget, With Medicare Still a Sticking Point
